summary:
North Macedonia is a country in Southeast Europe, landlocked and bordered by Greece, Albania, Bulgaria, Kosovo, and Serbia. With a population of 1.83 million, the majority are ethnic Macedonians, and Albanians form a large minority. The capital, Skopje, is home to a quarter of the population.

Historically, the region was part of the Kingdom of Macedonia and later the Roman Empire. It experienced various rulers, including the Byzantine Empire, Slavic tribes, and the Ottoman Empire. After World War II, it became part of Yugoslavia and gained independence in 1991. A dispute with Greece led to the country being temporarily named "the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia" until it officially changed its name to the Republic of North Macedonia in 2019.
title: North Macedonia
